questions.text:
Statement A: The activated B lymphocytes will get proliferated and transformed into memory cells. 

 

Statement B: The CD8 proteins occur on the surface of T cells, which bind MHC-II proteins.

 

Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Ans. A) The statement A is true, the statement B is false

questions.text: The osmotically most active intracellular cation is:
All the following proteins are known as molecular motors, because of their involvement in intracellular trafficking except:
Which of the following contributes least to the osmolality of the plasma?
All of the following statements about the azurophilic granules of the neutrophils are correct except:
Which of the following will be synthesized by the smooth endoplasmic reticulum?
Most of the sodium in the body is present in:
The larvicidal major basic protein is secreted mainly from which of these blood cells?
The lipid bilayer is most permeable to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Urea 

 

Explanation

 

The lipid bilayer of cell membranes is selectively permeable, allowing certain substances to pass through more easily than others. Urea is a small, uncharged molecule that can diffuse freely across the lipid bilayer without the need for transport proteins. Its nonpolar nature allows it to dissolve in the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer, facilitating its movement between cells and their surrounding environment, urea along with water also follows lipid bilayer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: Insulin is a large, polar protein hormone. Due to its size and charge, it cannot easily diffuse through the lipid bilayer. Instead, insulin interacts with specific receptors on the cell surface to initiate cellular responses.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose is a polar molecule and cannot readily cross the lipid bilayer by simple diffusion. It requires facilitated diffusion through glucose transporters (such as GLUT proteins) to enter cells.

 

Option C. Sodium ions: Sodium ions (Na⁺) are charged particles and do not pass through the lipid bilayer easily. Their movement across cell membranes is typically mediated by ion channels or active transport mechanisms.

 

Educational objective:

 

Urea is the most permeable substance across the lipid bilayer due to its small size and uncharged, nonpolar characteristics, allowing it to diffuse freely through the cell membrane.

questions.text: The protein Claudin is associated with which of these transmembrane proteins?

In a medicine OPD, three patients are being evaluated for diabetes. They have been given a load of glucose to do oral glucose tolerance test. Based on the below graph, which patient is in the pre-diabetic state?
Glycogen phosphorylase can be regulated by all the following except:
Which of the following does not occur in mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fatty acid synthesis

 

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm, not in the mitochondria.

 

  • The process involves the fatty acid synthase complex, which functions in the cytosol.
  • NADPH (from the pentose phosphate pathway) is used in the synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation

 

  • Occurs in the mitochondrial matrix.
  • Involves breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA, which enters the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. DNA synthesis

 

  • Mitochondria have their own circular DNA.
  • Replication of mitochondrial DNA occurs inside mitochondria.

 

Option D. Protein synthesis

 

  • Mitochondria contain ribosomes (similar to prokaryotic ribosomes).
  • They synthesize some of their own proteins (mostly components of the electron transport chain).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondria are involved in energy production, fatty acid oxidation, calcium handling, apoptosis, and even some DNA/protein synthesis. However, fatty acid synthesis is a cytoplasmic process, making Option B the correct answer.

questions.text: Insulin promotes lipogenesis by all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibiting Pyruvate Dehydrogenase

 

Insulin promotes lipogenesis (fat synthesis) by enhancing the availability of substrates and activating enzymes involved in fatty acid synthesis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreasing cAMP

 

  • True statement: Insulin activates phosphodiesterase, which degrades cAMP.
  • Lower cAMP levels inhibit hormone-sensitive lipase, thus reducing lipolysis and promoting lipogenesis.
  • Occurs under insulin action

 

Option B. Increasing Glucose uptake 

 

  • True statement: Insulin stimulates GLUT-4 transporters in adipose tissue and muscle, increasing glucose uptake.
  • Glucose provides glycerol-3-phosphate (for triglyceride synthesis) and acetyl-CoA (for fatty acid synthesis).
  • Supports lipogenesis

 

Option C. Inhibiting Pyruvate Dehydrogenase

 

  • False statement: Insulin activates, not inhibits, pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH).
  • PDH converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, which is the primary substrate for fatty acid synthesis.
  • So, inhibiting PDH would reduce acetyl-CoA → decrease lipogenesis.
  • Does NOT occur under insulin action → Correct answer

 

Option D. Increasing Acetyl CoA

 

  • True statement: Insulin indirectly increases acetyl-CoA by:
    • Promoting glycolysis → more pyruvate
    • Activating PDH → more acetyl-CoA
  • Acetyl-CoA is the building block for fatty acid synthesis.
  • Favors lipogenesis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin promotes lipogenesis by stimulating glucose uptake, glycolysis, and activation of pyruvate dehydrogenase, all of which enhance acetyl-CoA availability. It also reduces cAMP, thereby inhibiting lipolysis. Hence, the only action insulin does not perform is inhibiting pyruvate dehydrogenase.

questions.text: In the metabolic pathways, compounds destined to undergo certain biochemical reactions needs to be activated by addition of a high energy groups. All of the following can act as donor of such groups except:

A professional cyclist has been preparing for a long race competition. To guarantee that muscle glycogen is stored after the workout, his coach strongly advises that he consume carbs. Which of the following will most likely cause an increase in the activity of rate limiting enzyme of muscle glycogenesis under such resting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dephosphorylation 

 

After a workout and during rest, the body focuses on replenishing energy stores, especially muscle glycogen. This process is stimulated by insulin and resting (non-stress) conditions.

 

Muscle Glycogenesis and Its Rate-Limiting Enzyme:

 

  • The rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenesis is glycogen synthase.
  • Glycogen synthase is active in its dephosphorylated form.
  • Insulin promotes dephosphorylation via activation of protein phosphatase-1, thus stimulating glycogen synthesis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Glucagon

 

  • Mainly acts on the liver, not muscle.
  • Promotes glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, not glycogenesis.

 

Option B. Epinephrine

 

  • Released during stress/exercise.
  • Activates glycogen phosphorylase via phosphorylation, promoting glycogen breakdown.
  • Opposes glycogen synthesis.

 

Option C. Phosphorylation

 

  • Inactivates glycogen synthase.
  • Common during stress or exercise (via PKA, phosphorylase kinase).

questions.text: Acetyl CoA can be converted into all of the following except:
In glycolysis the first committed step is catalysed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 

 

In glycolysis, three enzymes catalyze irreversible steps, but only one is considered the first committed step—meaning once this step happens, the cell is fully committed to metabolizing glucose via glycolysis.

 

  • Catalyzes: Fructose-6-phosphate → Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate
  • This step commits the molecule to glycolysis
  • Rate-limiting and highly regulated step
    • Activated by: AMP, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
    • Inhibited by: ATP, citrate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

  • Not part of glycolysis.
  • Converts pyruvate → acetyl-CoA in mitochondria.
  • Important for entry into TCA cycle, after glycolysis.

 

Option B. Glucokinase (and also Hexokinase – see C)

 

  • Converts glucose → glucose-6-phosphate (G6P)
  • Not the committed step, because G6P can:
    • Enter glycolysis
    • Be used in the pentose phosphate pathway
    • Be stored as glycogen
  • Not specific to glycolysis

 

Option C. Hexokinase

 

  • Similar function as glucokinase but found in most tissues (glucokinase is liver-specific).
  • Same reason as above: not committed to glycolysis.

questions.text: Acetyl-CoA is a common intermediate formed from metabolism of carbohydrate, protein and lipid catabolism under fed and fasting states. Which of the following is the major source of acetyl CoA under fed state?

choices.text: Increased conversion of FA to Acetyl CoA

questions.text: A patient with Type I Diabetes presented with complains of polyuria. Which of the following will normally occur in his body?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased conversion of FA to Acetyl CoA
